questions.question: Alfred Sturtevant constructed the first:
questions.explanation: Alfred Sturtevant, Morgan's student, used recombination frequencies to construct the first genetic (linkage) map of X chromosome in Drosophila, showing relative positions of genes.

questions.question: In humans, sex of the child is determined by:
questions.explanation: In humans, the father determines the sex of the child. All eggs carry X chromosome, while sperm can carry either X or Y. If X-sperm fertilizes, child is XX (female); if Y-sperm, child is XY (male).

questions.question: ZW-ZZ system of sex determination is found in:
questions.explanation: In birds, females are heterogametic (ZW) and males are homogametic (ZZ). This is opposite to mammals. Female determines the sex of offspring by contributing either Z or W chromosome.

questions.question: ABO blood groups are an example of:
questions.explanation: ABO blood groups show multiple allelism (three alleles: I^A, I^B, i) and codominance (I^A and I^B are codominant). I^A and I^B are both dominant over i. This determines four blood types: A, B, AB, O.

questions.question: Features of Klinefelter syndrome include:
options: Feminine features like gynecomastia and sterility
questions.explanation: Klinefelter syndrome males show some feminine characteristics like gynecomastia (breast development), sparse body hair, small testes, and are usually sterile due to improper development of secondary sexual characters.

questions.question: Sex determination in humans is:
questions.explanation: Humans follow XX-XY sex determination system. Females have two X chromosomes (XX) and males have one X and one Y chromosome (XY). Sex is determined by the sperm (X or Y) that fertilizes the egg.

questions.question: The law of dominance states that:
options: One allele masks the expression of the other
questions.explanation: The Law of Dominance states that when two contrasting alleles are present (heterozygous), one (dominant) masks the expression of the other (recessive). The dominant trait is expressed in the phenotype.

questions.question: Codominance is exhibited by:
questions.explanation: Codominance is exhibited by ABO blood groups where both A and B alleles are expressed in AB blood group (I^A I^B). Neither allele is dominant or recessive to the other; both express simultaneously.

questions.question: Features of Down syndrome include:
options: Small round head with furrowed tongue
questions.explanation: Down syndrome is characterized by mental retardation, short stature, small round head, flat face, protruding furrowed tongue, partially open mouth, epicanthal fold, and simian crease on palm.

questions.question: Universal blood donor has blood group:
questions.explanation: Blood group O is the universal donor because O negative RBCs have no A, B, or Rh antigens and can be transfused to any blood group without causing agglutination reaction.

questions.question: In honeybees, drones are:
questions.explanation: Drones (male honeybees) are haploid (n=16) as they develop from unfertilized eggs by parthenogenesis. Queens and workers (females) are diploid (2n=32) from fertilized eggs.

questions.question: Turner syndrome is characterized by:
questions.explanation: Turner syndrome females have 45, X karyotype (44 autosomes + X). They are missing one X chromosome, resulting in total 45 chromosomes. It is the only viable monosomy in humans.

questions.question: The chromosomal theory of inheritance was proposed by:
questions.explanation: The Chromosomal Theory of Inheritance was proposed independently by Walter Sutton and Theodor Boveri in 1902-1903. They proposed that chromosomes are the physical carriers of genes.

questions.question: How many alleles control ABO blood groups?
questions.explanation: Three alleles (I^A, I^B, and i) control ABO blood groups. I^A codes for A antigen, I^B for B antigen, and i produces no antigen. Any individual has only two of these alleles.

questions.question: Haplodiploidy sex determination is seen in:
questions.explanation: Honeybees show haplodiploidy where males (drones) develop from unfertilized eggs (haploid, n) and females (queens and workers) from fertilized eggs (diploid, 2n). No sex chromosomes are involved.

questions.question: Queen Victoria was a carrier of:
questions.explanation: Queen Victoria was a carrier of haemophilia and transmitted it to many European royal families through her descendants. This is why haemophilia was once called the 'royal disease'.

questions.question: Polygenic inheritance involves:
questions.explanation: Polygenic inheritance (quantitative inheritance) involves multiple genes (polygenes) contributing to a single phenotypic trait. Examples include human skin color, height, and intelligence.

questions.question: Which is NOT a feature of pea plant that made it suitable for Mendel's experiments?
questions.explanation: Pea plants naturally self-pollinate, not cross-pollinate. The closed flower structure (keel) prevents cross-pollination. Mendel had to manually cross-pollinate by removing anthers and transferring pollen.

questions.question: The law of independent assortment is applicable when genes are:
options: On different chromosomes or far apart on same chromosome
questions.explanation: Independent assortment occurs when genes are on different chromosomes or far apart on the same chromosome (so crossing over between them is frequent). Linked genes do not assort independently.

questions.question: Phenylketonuria is an example of:
questions.explanation: Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an example of pleiotropy where a single defective gene causes multiple effects: mental retardation, reduced hair and skin pigmentation, and other symptoms due to accumulation of phenylalanine.

questions.question: Recombination frequency is related to:
questions.explanation: Recombination frequency (RF) is directly proportional to the distance between linked genes on a chromosome. Greater the distance, higher the chance of crossing over and hence higher recombination frequency.

questions.question: In a cross between TtRr × TtRr, how many different phenotypes can be obtained?
questions.explanation: In a dihybrid cross (TtRr × TtRr), 4 different phenotypes are produced: T_R_ (both dominant), T_rr (T dominant, r recessive), ttR_ (t recessive, R dominant), ttrr (both recessive) in 9:3:3:1 ratio.

questions.question: According to the law of segregation:
questions.explanation: The Law of Segregation states that during gamete formation, the two alleles of a gene separate (segregate) so that each gamete receives only one allele. This occurs during meiosis.

questions.question: In a monohybrid cross, the phenotypic ratio in F2 generation is:
questions.explanation: In a monohybrid cross (Tt × Tt), the F2 generation shows a phenotypic ratio of 3:1 (3 dominant : 1 recessive). The genotypic ratio is 1:2:1 (TT:Tt:tt).

questions.question: If a test cross produces all dominant phenotype offspring, the unknown parent is:
questions.explanation: If test cross (unknown × tt) produces all dominant offspring, the unknown must be homozygous dominant (TT). Cross: TT × tt → all Tt (dominant phenotype).

questions.question: Super female syndrome (47, XXX) is characterized by:
options: Usually normal but may have learning difficulties
questions.explanation: Super females (47, XXX) are usually normal in appearance and fertility. Some may have mild learning difficulties. The condition is often undiagnosed because symptoms are mild or absent.

questions.question: Y-linked traits are also called:
questions.explanation: Y-linked traits are called holandric traits because they are transmitted only from father to son (through Y chromosome). Examples in humans include hairy ear pinna (hypertrichosis).

questions.question: Chromosomal disorders can be due to:
questions.explanation: Chromosomal disorders can result from aneuploidy (gain/loss of chromosome), polyploidy (multiple sets of chromosomes), or structural changes (deletion, duplication, translocation, inversion).

questions.question: True breeding line is one that:
options: Produces offspring identical to parent for many generations
questions.explanation: A true breeding line (pure line) is one that has undergone continuous self-pollination and produces offspring identical to the parent for the trait being studied. It is homozygous for that trait.

questions.question: 1% recombination frequency equals:
questions.explanation: 1% recombination frequency equals 1 centiMorgan (cM) or 1 map unit. This measure is used to construct genetic maps showing relative positions of genes on chromosomes.

questions.question: The chromosomal constitution in Down syndrome is:
questions.explanation: Down syndrome individuals have 45 autosomes (with trisomy 21) + XX or XY = 47 chromosomes total. The karyotype is written as 47, XX+21 or 47, XY+21.

questions.question: Epistasis is:
options: One gene masking expression of another gene
questions.explanation: Epistasis is a form of gene interaction where one gene (epistatic gene) masks or modifies the expression of another gene (hypostatic gene) at a different locus. Example: coat color in mice.

questions.question: Number of Barr bodies in Klinefelter syndrome (XXY) is:
questions.explanation: Number of Barr bodies = Number of X chromosomes - 1. In XXY (Klinefelter), there is 1 Barr body. In XX female, 1 Barr body. In XO (Turner), 0 Barr bodies.

questions.question: In coat color of mice, the gene for color deposition is epistatic to:
questions.explanation: In mice, the C gene (color deposition) is epistatic to B gene (black/brown color). cc mice are albino regardless of B genotype because no pigment is deposited. Only C_ mice show black (B_) or brown (bb).

questions.question: Pleiotropy refers to:
questions.explanation: Pleiotropy is when a single gene influences multiple phenotypic traits. Example: sickle cell anemia gene affects RBC shape, causes anemia, affects multiple organs, and provides malaria resistance.

questions.question: The phenomenon where genes of parental types tend to remain together is:
questions.explanation: Linkage is the tendency of genes located on the same chromosome to be inherited together. Parental combinations appear more frequently than recombinant types due to linkage.

questions.question: If recombination frequency between two genes is 50%, the genes are:
options: On different chromosomes or far apart
questions.explanation: 50% recombination frequency indicates independent assortment, meaning genes are either on different chromosomes or so far apart on the same chromosome that crossing over between them is very frequent.

questions.question: Incomplete dominance is seen in:
questions.explanation: Incomplete dominance is seen in snapdragon (Antirrhinum) flower color where red (RR) × white (rr) produces pink (Rr) heterozygotes. Neither allele is completely dominant over the other.

questions.question: Sickle cell anemia is caused by substitution of:
options: Glutamic acid by lysine in β-globin
Glutamic acid by valine in β-globin
Valine by glutamic acid in β-globin
questions.explanation: Sickle cell anemia results from a point mutation in β-globin gene where glutamic acid (GAG) is replaced by valine (GUG) at position 6. This causes hemoglobin molecules to aggregate, deforming RBCs.

questions.question: Which of the following cannot be inherited from father to son?
questions.explanation: X-linked traits cannot pass from father to son because sons inherit Y chromosome (not X) from their father. Sons get their only X chromosome from their mother.

questions.question: Monosomy means:
questions.explanation: Monosomy refers to the presence of only one copy of a particular chromosome instead of two (2n-1). Example: Turner syndrome (45, XO) where one X chromosome is missing.

questions.question: In codominance:
options: Alleles blend to produce intermediate phenotype
One allele dominates over the other
questions.explanation: In codominance, both alleles of a heterozygote are fully expressed and contribute to the phenotype. Both gene products are produced, as seen in AB blood group where both A and B antigens are present.

questions.question: Point mutation involves:
questions.explanation: Point mutation is a change in a single base pair in DNA. It can be substitution (transition or transversion), insertion, or deletion of a single nucleotide. Example: sickle cell anemia results from a point mutation.

questions.question: In a dihybrid cross, the phenotypic ratio in F2 generation is:
questions.explanation: In a dihybrid cross (RrYy × RrYy), the F2 phenotypic ratio is 9:3:3:1 (9 round yellow : 3 round green : 3 wrinkled yellow : 1 wrinkled green), assuming independent assortment.

questions.question: A person with blood group AB has genotype:
questions.explanation: Blood group AB is produced by genotype I^A I^B, where both alleles are codominant and expressed. The person has both A and B antigens on RBCs and no antibodies in plasma.

questions.question: Pedigree analysis is used to:
questions.explanation: Pedigree analysis involves studying inheritance patterns of traits across generations in a family using pedigree charts. It helps determine if a trait is dominant/recessive, autosomal/sex-linked.

questions.question: Universal blood recipient has blood group:
questions.explanation: Blood group AB is the universal recipient because AB positive individuals have no anti-A, anti-B, or anti-Rh antibodies in plasma and can receive blood from any ABO/Rh group.

questions.question: In a monohybrid cross, the genotypic ratio in F2 generation is:
questions.explanation: In a monohybrid cross (Tt × Tt), the F2 genotypic ratio is 1:2:1 (1 TT : 2 Tt : 1 tt). The 1 TT and 2 Tt show the dominant phenotype while tt shows recessive.

questions.question: Features of Turner syndrome include:
questions.explanation: Turner syndrome females are short, have webbed neck, shield-shaped chest, undeveloped gonads (streak gonads), lack secondary sexual characters, have amenorrhea (no menstruation), and are sterile.

questions.question: The law of segregation is also called:
questions.explanation: The Law of Segregation is also called the Law of Purity of Gametes because it states that alleles separate during gamete formation, and each gamete receives only one allele of a gene (pure for that allele).

questions.question: In incomplete dominance, the phenotypic ratio in F2 is:
questions.explanation: In incomplete dominance, F2 phenotypic ratio is 1:2:1 (same as genotypic ratio) because heterozygotes can be distinguished phenotypically. Example: 1 red : 2 pink : 1 white.

questions.question: Genes located on the same chromosome are called:
questions.explanation: Genes located on the same chromosome are called linked genes. They tend to be inherited together and do not show independent assortment unless crossing over separates them.

questions.question: Non-disjunction occurs during:
questions.explanation: Non-disjunction (failure of chromosomes to separate properly) can occur during both mitosis and meiosis. During meiosis, it leads to gametes with abnormal chromosome numbers causing aneuploid offspring.

questions.question: Phenotype refers to:
questions.explanation: Phenotype is the observable physical or biochemical characteristics of an organism determined by genotype and environment. Genotype is the genetic constitution. Phenotype = Genotype + Environment.

questions.question: If a test cross produces 1:1 ratio of phenotypes, the unknown parent is:
questions.explanation: If test cross produces 1:1 ratio (50% dominant : 50% recessive), the unknown parent is heterozygous (Tt). Cross: Tt × tt → 1 Tt : 1 tt.

questions.question: A colour blind man marries a carrier woman. The probability of their son being colour blind is:
questions.explanation: Cross: X^c Y × X^+ X^c → Sons: X^+ Y (normal) or X^c Y (colour blind) = 50% each. Sons inherit X from mother (50% chance of getting X^c) and Y from father.

questions.question: T.H. Morgan's work on linkage and recombination was done on:
questions.explanation: T.H. Morgan conducted extensive genetic studies on Drosophila melanogaster (fruit fly). He demonstrated linkage, recombination, sex-linkage, and helped establish the chromosomal theory of inheritance.

questions.question: Haemophilia is:
questions.explanation: Haemophilia (failure of blood clotting) is an X-linked recessive disorder. It is more common in males because they have only one X chromosome. The gene codes for clotting factor VIII (Haemophilia A).

questions.question: Down syndrome is caused by:
questions.explanation: Down syndrome is caused by trisomy of chromosome 21 (three copies instead of two), resulting in 47 chromosomes. It is characterized by mental retardation, short stature, and distinctive facial features.

questions.question: Human skin color is controlled by:
questions.explanation: Human skin color is a polygenic trait controlled by at least 3-4 genes (some estimates suggest more). Each gene has two alleles, and the phenotype depends on the total number of dominant alleles.

questions.question: Mendel studied how many contrasting pairs of traits in pea plants?
questions.explanation: Mendel studied 7 contrasting pairs of traits: stem height (tall/dwarf), flower color (violet/white), flower position (axial/terminal), pod shape (inflated/constricted), pod color (green/yellow), seed shape (round/wrinkled), and seed color (yellow/green).

questions.question: Linkage was discovered by:
questions.explanation: Linkage was first discovered by Bateson and Punnett in sweet pea while studying flower color and pollen shape. They observed that certain combinations appeared together more often than expected.

questions.question: Recombinant offspring have:
options: Same combination of alleles as parents
questions.explanation: Recombinant offspring have new combinations of alleles that differ from either parent. These arise from crossing over between linked genes during meiosis.

questions.question: In a cross TtRr × TtRr, how many genotypes can be obtained?
questions.explanation: In a dihybrid cross, 9 different genotypes are produced: TTRR, TTRr, TTrr, TtRR, TtRr, Ttrr, ttRR, ttRr, ttrr. There are 16 offspring combinations but only 9 unique genotypes.

questions.question: The Law of Independent Assortment states that:
options: Genes on same chromosome assort together
Alleles of one gene segregate with alleles of another gene
Alleles of different genes assort independently during gamete formation
questions.explanation: The Law of Independent Assortment states that alleles of different genes located on different chromosomes assort independently during gamete formation. This is the basis for the 9:3:3:1 ratio.

questions.question: Mendel's work was rediscovered in 1900 by:
options: de Vries, Correns, and von Tschermak
questions.explanation: Mendel's work, published in 1866, was rediscovered independently in 1900 by three scientists: Hugo de Vries (Netherlands), Carl Correns (Germany), and Erich von Tschermak (Austria).

questions.question: If an autosomal recessive trait appears in offspring of unaffected parents:
questions.explanation: If unaffected parents have affected offspring for an autosomal recessive trait, both parents must be carriers (heterozygotes, Aa). Cross: Aa × Aa → 1 AA : 2 Aa : 1 aa (25% affected).

questions.question: Punnett square is used to:
questions.explanation: A Punnett square is a diagram used to predict the genotypes and phenotypes of offspring from a genetic cross. It shows all possible combinations of parental gametes.

questions.question: Alleles are:
options: Alternative forms of the same gene
questions.explanation: Alleles are alternative forms of the same gene that occupy the same locus on homologous chromosomes. They may code for different versions of the same trait (e.g., T for tall, t for dwarf).

questions.question: Trisomy means:
questions.explanation: Trisomy refers to the presence of three copies of a particular chromosome instead of two (2n+1). Examples include Down syndrome (trisomy 21), Klinefelter syndrome (XXY).

questions.question: Crossing over occurs during:
questions.explanation: Crossing over occurs during pachytene stage of prophase I of meiosis. Homologous chromosomes exchange segments at chiasmata, creating new combinations of alleles (recombination).

questions.question: Klinefelter syndrome is characterized by:
questions.explanation: Klinefelter syndrome males have 47, XXY karyotype (44 autosomes + XXY). They have an extra X chromosome, resulting in overall 47 chromosomes.

questions.question: In grasshopper, males have:
questions.explanation: Grasshoppers follow XO sex determination. Males have only one X chromosome (XO), while females have two (XX). Males produce two types of sperm (with X or without sex chromosome).

questions.question: A haemophiliac man marries a normal woman. Their daughters will be:
questions.explanation: Cross: X^h Y × X^H X^H → Daughters: X^H X^h (all carriers). Daughters receive X^h from father and X^H from mother, making them heterozygous carriers.

questions.question: A test cross is a cross between:
questions.explanation: A test cross is a cross between an organism of unknown genotype (showing dominant phenotype) and a homozygous recessive individual. It helps determine if the unknown is homozygous or heterozygous.

questions.question: An individual with 47, XYY karyotype is called:
questions.explanation: 47, XYY individuals are called super males or Jacob syndrome. They are usually taller than average, may have mild learning difficulties, but are generally fertile and have normal appearance.

questions.question: A colour blind man marries a normal woman. Their sons will be:
questions.explanation: Cross: X^c Y (colour blind man) × X^+ X^+ (normal woman) → Sons: X^+ Y (all normal). Sons inherit X from mother (normal) and Y from father. The father's X^c goes only to daughters.

questions.question: Aneuploidy refers to:
options: Gain or loss of one or more chromosomes
questions.explanation: Aneuploidy is a condition where one or more chromosomes are added or missing from the normal diploid number (2n±1, 2n±2, etc.). It usually results from non-disjunction during meiosis.

questions.question: In incomplete dominance, the F1 phenotype is:
options: Different from both parents but not intermediate
questions.explanation: In incomplete dominance, the F1 heterozygote shows a phenotype intermediate between the two parents. For example, red × white = pink in snapdragon.

questions.question: In a pedigree chart, a filled circle represents:
questions.explanation: In pedigree charts: square = male, circle = female; filled (shaded) = affected, empty = unaffected. A filled circle therefore represents an affected female.

questions.question: Sex-linked genes are located on:
questions.explanation: Sex-linked genes are located on sex chromosomes (X or Y). Most sex-linked traits in humans are X-linked because X chromosome carries many more genes than Y chromosome.

questions.question: Colour blindness is:
questions.explanation: Colour blindness (red-green color blindness) is an X-linked recessive trait. Males are more commonly affected because they have only one X chromosome and no corresponding allele on Y to mask the defective gene.

questions.question: Crisscross inheritance is seen in:
questions.explanation: Crisscross inheritance occurs in X-linked traits where males inherit the trait from their mother (through X chromosome) and transmit it to their daughters. Fathers cannot transmit X-linked traits to sons.

questions.question: Mendel selected pea plant for his experiments because:
options: Self-pollination and cross-pollination are easily possible
It has short life cycle and produces many seeds
questions.explanation: Mendel chose pea plant because it has clearly distinguishable contrasting traits, short generation time, produces many offspring, can self-pollinate naturally, and cross-pollination can be easily performed.

questions.question: Which disorder is caused by trisomy of chromosome 18?
questions.explanation: Edward syndrome is caused by trisomy 18 (three copies of chromosome 18). It is characterized by severe developmental delay, heart defects, and often early death. Patau syndrome is trisomy 13.

questions.question: A person with blood group O has genotype:
questions.explanation: Blood group O is produced by genotype ii (homozygous recessive). The person has no A or B antigens on RBCs but has both anti-A and anti-B antibodies in plasma.

questions.question: Homozygous condition means:
questions.explanation: Homozygous means having two identical alleles for a trait (TT or tt). Heterozygous means having two different alleles (Tt). Homozygotes are true breeding for that trait.

questions.question: Barr body is:
questions.explanation: Barr body is the inactive X chromosome in female mammals, visible as a dark-staining body in the nucleus. X-inactivation (Lyon hypothesis) ensures dosage compensation - only one X is active in each cell.
